South America, East, South and West Africa,
India, Australia, New Zealand, China and Japan.

To secure quick transmission, telegrams should
be marked Via Eastern.

div.head: KHEDIVIAL MAIL LINE.
div.p: Express Steamers leave Alexandria every Wednesday at 4 p.m. for PIRAEUS, SMYRNA, MITYLENE, and CONSTANTINOPLE, in connection with Orient Express train-de-luxe for Vienna, Paris, and London.

Fast steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 6 p.m., and Port Said every Sunday at 6 p.m., for JAFFA (for Jerusalem), CAIFFA (for Nazareth), BEYROUT (for Damascus), TRIPOLI, ALEXANDRETTA, MESSINA, continuing in alternate weeks to LARNACA and LIMASSOL (Cyprus).

Steamers leave Suez fortnightly on Wednesday at 6 p.m. for JEDDAH, SUAKIN, MASSOWAH, HODBIDAH, and ADEN ; and in the intervening weeks for PORT SUDAN and SUAKIN direct. Calls will be made at TOR (for Mount Sinai) as required.
N.B.—Deck chairs provided for the use of passengers, excellent cuisine and table wine free.
Steamer plans may be seen and passages booked at the Company’s Agencies at Alexandria, Cairo, Port Said, and Suez, or at THOS. COOK & SON or other Tourist Agency.

Five at Meharrem Bey.
Yesterday evening at about eleven o'clock a fire broke ont in a paper factory belonging to Mr. Lagoudakis at Moharrem Bey. The fire brigade, under the command of Superintendent
_ Waller, on receiving the alarm made all haste

to the spot, but owing-to the distance they had to go the fire had made considerable headway before their arrrival. Though the fire was soon got under control, it was not until six o'clock this morning that the brigade were able to leave the building. ‘The fire is believed. to have heen due to spontaneous combustion, and has involved the destruction of 200 tons of paper
anil 60 tops of rags. The loss is covered by
ins irance. f
Energetic preparations are being made by the committee appointed to superintend the
- arrangements fot celebrating the French Nat-
ional Pete, to be held on the 14th July. [fone may judge by, the interest with which the
yesidents of Cairo have been discussing the

coming event, the complete success of the commemoration of the establishment of a Republic in France should be already assured. To-morrow evening the committee intend to hold another meeting, to consider to the decora- tion..and illumination of the Esbekieh Garden, which excellent position has been again placed at their disposal by the Egyptian authorities ; but, we understand, that certain reservations have been made in regard to firework displays and more especially relative to thie use of rockets.

PAYMENT SUSPENDED.
(Gazette's Specia! Service.)

London, Wednesday. The “Temps” states that the Abyssinian Railway Company is unable to. meet Coupons bonds due, and have suspended payment. The French Envoy at, Abyssinia has been instructed to see to measures it is expedient to take for the preservation and exploitation of thepart of the line already built. Also to look after negotiations pending with King Menelik concerning the projected extension of the line to Addis Abeba.

COLLAPSE OF A HUT.

As we go to press we are informed that a native hut in Rae Ibrahim, Minet-el-Bassal quarter, collapsed at noon to-day. Four natives were buried underneath, but were immediately extracted by the fire brigade, aiid are still alive although severely injured. They have been taken to the hospital by the Society ‘Soccorsi d'Urgenza.”
DISTRICT POST OFFICES,

We have at different periods, as well as several of the local papers, called attention to the urgent need of a district post office for the important quarter of Ismailieh in Cairo, which together with the adjacent quarters of Tewfi- kieh, Kasr-el-Nil and Bab-el-Lowk, cc mprise the best residential parts of the capital, and in’ which are situated all the banks, commercial companies and leading firms. These combined must have a population approximately at least 150,000 inhabitants and the nearest post office at present is the one at Ataba-el-Khadra, quite two iniles from Kasr-el-Nil or Tewfikieh. The postal administration has opened district offi- ces in far less important parts of the capital, for example at Faggalla, Bab-el-Khalk and Nasrieh and we think it is high time that steps should be at once taken to Yemedy this deficiency for the quarters that require a dis- trict. office far more than any of the latter.
BONAPARTE IN EGYPT.

Some little time ago we referred to the approaching publication of a new work on Egypt which a well-known: London publisher has announced. We now learn that this work will be issued towards the end of this month and that it will appear as “Bonaparte in Egypt and the Egyptians of to-day.” Theauthor is Mr. H. A. Browne, who for over thirty years has been known far and wide in the East as a staunch advocate of English interests, and one who has a ‘more intimate acquaintance with the life of the East than any other European. From Caleutta to Constantinople and thence to Cape Town, Mr. Browne has travelled far and long, and always as an Eastern, and so thoroughly has his inéognito, for it cannot be described as a disguise, been maintained that more than once he has had great difficulty in establishing his real character. Thus at Tiflis the Rusian officials refused to accept his English passports, insisting upon recording him as an Arnout or Albanian Mahomedan and much to his discomfort treating him accord- ingly. Again at Constantinople he had to face the same difficulty, the officials there even going so far as to arrest him and chaage him with travelling with false passports. He was more fortunate at Astrabad in Persia, where the Russian Consul while refusing to grant him a visa on his English passports gave him a new passport describing him as “believed to be of Turki@ origin.” Even in India, nig 2a, 8 5 who might be supposed to have avery keen scent for the detection ofan Englishman what- ever character he might choose to adopt, have mere than once insisted upon treating him as an oriental. With sach an experience of the East to guide him it would be strange if any- thing that Mr. Browne has tosay about the East should hot be worth hearing.

TRE LOST DETACHMENT) CAIRO BUILDING SITES.
NATIONALIST CRITICS.

We hear on good authority that the sad loss of the Sudanese patrol in the Western Desest, between Dongola and the Arbani road, was entirely due to the fact that the party left the Bir Natron wells for Abou Tabari, where there is a good water supply, under the con- duct ot a guide who declared that he knew the
road, but none the léss lost his way, and only’

admitted his mistake when the unfortunate patrol had exhausted their water supply, which was quite sufficient to last for the whole journey from Natron to Abu Tabari had the guide only known the road. We believe that these localities are from 100 to 150 miles E. of the Nile and are therefore not in such eas reach of the telegraph as our Nationalist erities, who are of course making all the capital they can make out of the incident, pretend. The insinuation that the men were
sent without guides into the desert is absurd. | M

Were this the custom of the military author ities in the Sudan they would’ soon have no troops left! The days when an Egyptian war vessel searched the Mediterranean in vain for Malta and returned with the news “Malta mafeesh” arepast. Then there was no press to expose the mismanagement which could lead to so comic and so humiliatihg an incident. Now the mistake of a Inckless guide, which seems to have cost him his life is brought up against the War Office and the Sudan Govern- ment by their self appointed critics, who having never done any desert work on camels, do not realise the dangers that beset the best equipped expeditions. nities
PRESS OF EGYPT.
INTERESTING STATISTICS.

Artin Pasha _ca@mtributes an interesting articles to the “Bulletin de I'Institut Egyptien” giving the statisties of the Press in Egypt up to the end of 1904. According to this article tliere were in 1839 two newspapers, one in Arabic ahd one in Turkish, in 1868 there were 3 French, 2 Italian, 1 Arabic and Turkish and 1 Arabic journal ; in 1889 15 Arabic, 8 French, 1 English-French, ‘4 Italian and 5 Greek ; and in 1904-the figures were as follows Arabie 118, French 17,French-English 3, Italian 6, Greek 15, French-English-Arabie 2, English 3, Hebrew 1, French-Arabie 1, English-Arabic 1, -Italian-Arabie 1, Italian- French 2, Armenian 3, and Turkish 3. Of the journals being published at the end of 1904; 29 were daily, 4 three times a week, 6 twice a week, 76 weekly, 24 twice a month, and 37 monthly. Of the 33 papers published in 1889 only 16 continued to 1904. ;
JEWISH COLONISATION IN THE SUDAN.

According to the “Jewish World” M. Galante, a Cairo gentleman of the Jewish persuasion, is at-work on a great scheme which, “should it be carried into execution, will render im- portant services to our co-teligionists from Russia and Roumania who come to this country. This scheme is one of Jewish coloni- sation in the Sudan, and with facts to support his contention M. Galante shows that this- region, which is practically an English colony, offers a vast field for agricultural and com- mercial industries. Some philanthropic societies
and emihent co-religionists are in ‘constant | i

correspondence with M. Galante, and are discussing with him the question of sending a commission to the Sudaw to study its. topo- graphy, climate, ete. Anybody who knows the territory watered by the Nile will, without doubt, recognise its suitability for the object just mentioned.”
COTTON MILLS OF JAPAN.

At the annual general meeting of the Kobe Board ot Trade the President remarked that the cotton mills of Japan during 1906 hada most successful year,’ their production being sold out for some months aheathalmost all the year round. The Canadian Commercial Agent at Yokohama reports that large dividends were earned by the better class of spin- ning mills, Sand ,a considerable ingrease of spiules would be made this year. Prices of yarns dropped somewhat in the summer months, but advanced towards the end of the year, The quantity exported was some 1,000 pieuls (1 picul equals 133lb,) less than tor 1905, though the value shows an increase of 1,500,000 yen. The market generally wasin a very healthy condition,and with a good demand from China on account of the increase in the price of silver, mills generally are in a most tlourishing condition,and one or two have made arrangements for an increase of capital. From another source the Canadian Commercial t states that the cotton-spinning industry, whi made considerable progress after the Japan- China War,does not indicate so great a relative expansion under the influence of the present
speculative mania assome other i
industries. He
goes on to say that the demand for cotton |

yarn and cotton cloth for home consamption,is increasing year after year, and the export, mainly to the Asiatic mainland, is also in- creasing. In all respects there is an assurance felt that new conipanies have a promising future.

NO PALL IN PRICES.

A correspondent writes :—There seems to be an idea that prices of building sites in the better residential districts of the Capital are fallixig, or that we may expect a’ dropin the near*future, but such an idea is ¢ fallacious, and not borne out by faets, for sit
suitable for building purposes have, on the

contrary, been steadily increasing all the winter, and even at this moment there is only a momentary lull, which is. usual at the dull season of the year, but no relapse from former values is apparent from the recent sales. For example, a plot belonging to the’Société Im- mobilitre in the Sharia Kasr-el-Nil changed hands a short time back at L.E. 36 the square metre, whilst for another plot, known as the Maison Borelli, in Sharia Soliman Pasha, no less than L.E. 40 is being asked. Lots on the property formerly belonging to the Prince i, opposite the Savey Hotel, cannot be had at this moment under LE. 50 to L.E. 60 the metre. There is a momeutary suspension also in the active negotiations prevailing during the past winter season for land in the favorite suburbs—such as Gltezireh, Kasrel-Aly, Kasr-el-Doubara, and those of the Matarieh line—but this was to be expected, and doubtless in the coming autumn, dealings will be ‘as brisk as before in these directions for the good reason that as the population by immigration or otherwise, and rentals in the city keep at their present figures people are compelled to seek house accom- modation at reasonable prices elsewhere. This is likewise shown by the number of new hotels that are in contemplation in the immediate
- | suburbs, for those already existing in the town
are so crowded during the height.of the season that nambers of visitors are turned away daily, so great is the demafd for rooms and suites.
NOTES FROM SUEZ.
SHIPP{NG MOVEMENTS.
(From ovr own ConResPoNDENT).
Suez, Tuesday.

The Messageries Maritimes steamer “Koo- angsi,” from Japan arrived at Suez this morning with @ breakdown in her machinery, and was towed through the Canal by the tug “Titan.” She however came to Suez without assistance.
Owing to the 8.W. monsoon having begun in the Indian Ocean, all steamers are arriving a day or two late. The R M.S. “Ortona” which entered the Canal on Sunday last was up to her time. .
"THE INDUSTRIES OF GAZA.

British Consalar-Agent Knesevich, in a trade report says that Gaza is situated in the south-east of Palestine. and is only about, 12 miles to the north of Rafah, which marks the Turco-Egyptian ,boundary. It is the com- mercial and inistrative centre of all the surrounding villages and for many of the Bedouin tribes. who pitch their tents in the plains. The population of Gaza numbers about 40,000, while that of the surrounding villages ig about 70,000. The principal occupation of
hé people is agriculture ; only a small minor-
ity

During. the summer months (iaza is very busy numbers of people being employed in the export of barley, which is the chief product of the district. In: 1906, owing to the lateness and irregularity of the rains, the barley crop was less plentiful than in 1905, and only 12 ship-loads were taken against 26 ship-loads. in the previous year. Wheat, millet, and most of the fruits and vegetables of Palestine are also produced at Gaza. The manufactures of the place are limited to native necessaries, such as a rough and primitive kind of pottery, cotton garments, and sieves: ‘Thus, with the exception of grain, vegetables, and cattle; nearly everything bas to be imported. Mer- chants and traders import all their goods from Beirut and Jaffa, either by sea-on lighters or by land on camels. The long-talked-of jetty was at length completed on December 8, 1906. lt is only 60 métres long by 8 métres in width, and is not of much use for the ship- ment of barley. A custom-house was built on the beach at the begining of the year. A police station and a public garden were begun, but owing to ‘lack of funds the work
stopped and the site is offered for sale. The.

roads from Gaza to Jaffa and Beersheba are badly in need of repair. Beersheba, which was rebuilt five years ago, is growing steadily. During the year a mosque was built there and a public garden laid gut. One of the ancient
wells was opened and & pump placed on it to
supply the town with water,

_ AT THE RACES.

To tue Eprror or rue “Boveriaw Gazerre.” Sir,—From the recent correspondence in your columns, it appears, as is usually the case upon such a subject as this, that the question of “andesirable woman” visiting the races, is creating undeserved publicity. As a matter of fact until of this although I have been present at practically every race meeting at the Sporting Club this season, the “evil” referred to by “Paterfamilias” and an “Irate Husband” has failed to attract my notice. Troe my only object in going to the races is, as should be and I believe is, in the majority of cases, for the sport of the thing, and I may be no connoisseur in the art of discriminating the “black sheep” from the “white”: this I prefer to leave to “Paterfamilias” andan “Irate Husband”, since from their observa- tions this occupation of more interest to them than the racing. May I also ask your two correspondents whether they have seen any act of molestation, or anything approach- ing unbecoming behaviour on the part of the women referred to: if so then my powers of observation sadly need sharpening. I do not
wish to oceupy too much of your valuable | the

space, but while on the subject it also occurs to me togmention that if your correspondents had raised any objection to the glaring evil of the Boulevard de Ramleh as soon as dusk gets in, when molestation is the role rather than the exception, they might have met with some support, but their present complaint seems to me groundless. I entirely agree with “A Race- Goer” that solong as the “members’ enclosure” is made public, then no discrimination can be made,and if members wish only to associate with their own “select” clique, thenthey must be “penned” off in their own enclosure, and let the general public look after themselves. Yours truly, “SportsMay.” Alexandria, June 4, 1907.
To rae Bprror or tar “Eayprian Gazerre.”

Sir.—In reply to the letter of “Paterfamilias” and “Irate husband” I think I must side with | “Don Juan” and advise the irate husbands to install themselves at the entrance of the race- course, 80 as to be able to sort the race goers. Here in Alexandria everybody must admit that it is a very difficult thing to draw the line as to who are the black and. who are the white sheep of the fold, Moreover I fail to see how one could prevent the “Un desirables” going to the race-course when the same persons are admitt- ed to theatres, einematograph halls and all Other public places.
4 Yours trvly,
IMPARTIAL. Alexandria, June 5 1907.
To tae Eprror or tie “Eayptian Gazerre.”

Sir.—Very many people must welcome the letter of the other day signed “Paterfamilias” calling attention to the scandal of the Alex- andria Race Course. The grounds are private property kept up by the members, who are therefore quite at liberty to decide who may or who may not be admitted. The committee should therefore be called upon to take im- mediate action, as members will not continue to support a parade for the demi-monde, whose presence deters many people, members amongst others, from attending the races.
; Yours truly, ExcLupep.
: San Stefano, June 4, 1907.
WANTED A TORS
To tue Fprron or tae “Eayrtian Gazerre”

Sir, — “ Paterfamilias” and the “Irate Husband ” have raised a very amusing con- troversy in your paper. Have those gentlemen ever been on a race course outside Alexandria. There are one or two of us here who have seen the derby,and have also attended race meetings at Auteiul and Longchamps. We went to see the races and to put on our humble dollar or a pound if we were lucky, and I haven't met any one who passed a sleepless night on account of the moral aspect of the people he met onthe
course or courses, As an easy way out of] | difficulty let me humbly suggest that

the a committee be appointed at once, that delegates attend the turnstiles, aad that no one of the weaker sex be admitted to the Alexandiia race-course unless able to produce. at least two responsible _refer- ences. There are a lot of people who go through life looking for trouble and I think “Paterfamilias” and the “Irate Husband” belong to that number. The writer knows the East as far as the Philippines and he has never seen a better behaved Eastern town than Alexandria at night, or a better con- dueted race meeting than we have here.
“Paterfamilias” is keener sighted than most of us ; personally I see a lot of exceptionally well dressed women and there it ends.
. Your's truly. “Dioary rs.”

Cotons: Nouvelle récolte.—Le novembre a ouvert à 14 15/16 sous l'impression de la clôture d'Amérique et ne tarde même pas à fléchir à 14 7/8, mais il se raffermit de nouveau. Affaires claisemées.
Récolte actuelle. —Juillet a débuté à 14 5/16 et reste soutenu. Marché peu animé.

Fèves-Saidi: Nouvelle récolte.—Marché nul.

div.p: A BROKEN-DOWN SYSTEM.

This is a condition (or disease) to which doctors give many names, but which few of them really understand. It it simply weakness—a break-down, as it were, of the vital forces that sustain the system. No matter what may be its causes (for they are almost numberless), its symptoms are much the same; the more prominent being sleeplessness, sense of prostration or weariness, depression of spirits and want of energy for all the ordinary affairs of life. Now, what alone is absolutely essential in all such cases is increased vitality—vigour--
VITAL STRENGTH & ENERGY
to throw off these morbid feelings, and experience proves that as night succeeds the day this may be more certainly secured by a course of the celebrated life-reviving tonic
THERAPION No.3
than by any other known combination. So surely as it is taken in accordance with the printed directions accompanying it, will the shattered health be restored,
THE EXPIRING LAMP OF LIFE LIGHTED UP AFRESH,

and a new existence imparted in place of what had so lately seemed worn-out, "used up,” and valueless. This wonderful medicament is purely vegetable and innocuous, is agreeable to the taste —suitable for all constitutions and conditions, in either sex; and it is difficult to imagine a case of disease or derangement, whose main features are those of debility, that will not be speedily and permanently benefited by this never-failing recuperative essence, which is destined to cast into oblivion everything that had preceded it for this wide-spread and numerous class of human ailments.
THERAPION

is sold by the principal Chemists throughout the world. Price in England, 2 9 and 4/6.
